feed.title: Miranda Making Things
feed.subtitle: I'm a cell biologist turned programmer. This site is my blog and portfolio: my coding journey and the things I've made.

entry.title: No layout given
entry.content: A short post to see if I set up the default layout correctly.

entry.title: Job Hunting is Weird
entry.content:
Haha I wasn‚Äôt looking while I typed, I originally wrote joob hunjting. Yes, I am applying for joobs. For the first time since 2012!

At that time I had just finished my PhD and was looking for a postdoctoral research role. I think I applied to about six places. Science roles get very specialised very quickly - you‚Äôre expected to know the research field as well as the technology used. I remember one interview went particularly badly; it was something to do with liver disease, whereas my PhD was in breast cancer biology. I knew basically nothing about the liver. They weren‚Äôt impressed.

I‚Äôm sure I did a bad job of explaining how I could learn quickly, and how my experience was actually kind of relevant, and how I definitely did think livers are very cool and interesting. My PhD was an awful experience where initiative was simultaneously frowned upon (must obey the boss) and essential (boss had no ideas). My stipend had finished when I left the lab after 3 years on the dot, and I was living off a personal loan to cover my time writing up. So I was stressed, unhappy, and running out of money, but determined not to work in another bad lab.

When I arrived for the interview at UCL, where I ended up working, I totally forgot that I was supposed to be interrogating everyone to work out the real situation. The project just sounded so cool, and my future boss sold it really well. I got the job, and I got lucky: it was a good lab. My boss was admittedly rather eccentric, but with an incredible brain. It was an honour and an inspiration to work there for eight years.

And now I‚Äôm unemployed again. This time I‚Äôm not stressed and weird, I‚Äôm confident and accomplished. But it‚Äôs still weird! Partly because I haven‚Äôt worked out the optimum amount of time to spend job hunting, vs working on a project, vs learning a new language, vs enjoying not being in work.

The job hunting is 35% desperately scouring the internet for adverts with ‚Äúgraduate/junior/associate‚Äù in the title, 60% writing about how wonderful I am, and 5% making sure I get my green square on GitHub. That is a weird way to spend a day.

I‚Äôve applied to 4 jobs so far. Others in my Makers cohort have applied to over 50 places! I‚Äôve already developed a distaste for places which want more than a CV and a cover letter, where they want specific questions answered as well. Extra hoops for us to jump through. I think it‚Äôs disrespectful. I‚Äôm going to assign Mon-Wed as application days (boring days), and Thurs-Fri as coding days (fun days). Oh well! Soon I‚Äôll get a job and then every day will be a coding day. And hopefully this will be the last time I‚Äôm full-time job hunting.

I also spent ages trying to decide what hobby project to focus on - what would make me more employable? Should I relearn Python now so I can embark on the difficult Python project I‚Äôve planned? Maybe start an easier React or JavaScript project? Or something with Rails so I don‚Äôt forget it? Then I remembered that hobbies are supposed to be something fun that I want to do, regardless of usefulness. So I‚Äôm going to treat myself to implementing a light/dark colour scheme switch on this website. prefers-color-scheme here I come!

I listened to all of Muse‚Äôs back catalogue last week. Very enjoyable. They were one of the first bands I ever saw live, in 2001. I‚Äôve seen them 6-7 times since, at increasingly bigger venues. They always create a fantastic show. One of my friends once said she didn‚Äôt like them as they have no sense of humour. I still don‚Äôt understand how anyone can listen to this and think that.
entry.summary: Haha I wasn‚Äôt looking while I typed, I originally wrote joob hunjting. Yes, I am applying for joobs. For the first time since 2012!
